actor.table_description: The actor table lists information for all actors. The actor table is joined to the film table by means of the film_actor table.';

actor_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each actor in the table.
actor_id.name: actor_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

address.table_description: The address table contains address information for customers, staff, and stores. The address table primary key appears as a foreign key in the customer, staff, and store tables.';

address.description: The first line of an address.
address.name: address

address2.description: An optional second line of an address.
address2.name: address2

address_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each address in the table.
address_id.name: address_id

city_id.description: A foreign key pointing to the city table.
city_id.name: city_id

district.description: The region of an address, this may be a state, province, prefecture, etc.
district.name: district

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

location.description: A Geometry column with a spatial index on it.
location.name: location

phone.description: The telephone number for the address.
phone.name: phone

postal_code.description: The postal code or ZIP code of the address (where applicable).
postal_code.name: postal_code

category.table_description: The category table lists the categories that can be assigned to a film. The category table is joined to the film table by means of the film_category table.';

category_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each category in the table.
category_id.name: category_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

city.table_description: The city table contains a list of cities. It is referred to by a foreign key in the address table and refers to the country table using a foreign key.';

city_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each city in the table.
city_id.name: city_id

country_id.description: A foreign key identifying the country that the city belongs to.
country_id.name: country_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

country.table_description: The country table contains a list of countries. The country table is referred to by a foreign key in the city table.';

country_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each country in the table.
country_id.name: country_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

customer.table_description: The customer table contains a list of all customers. It is referred to in the payment and rental tables and refers to the address and store tables using foreign keys.';

active.description: Indicates whether the customer is an active customer. Setting this to FALSE serves as an alternative to deleting a customer outright. Most queries should have a WHERE active = TRUE clause.
active.name: active

address_id.description: A foreign key identifying the customer address in the address table.
address_id.name: address_id

create_date.description: The date the customer was added to the system. This date is automatically set using a trigger during an INSERT.
create_date.name: create_date

customer_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each customer in the table.
customer_id.name: customer_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

store_id.description: A foreign key identifying the customer "home store." Customers are not limited to renting only from this store, but this is the store at which they generally shop.
store_id.name: store_id

film.table_description: The film table is a list of all films potentially in stock in the stores. The actual in-stock copies of each film are represented in the inventory table. It refers to the language table and is referred to by the film_category, film_actor, and inventory tables.';

description.description: A short description or plot summary of the film.
description.name: description

film_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each film in the table.
film_id.name: film_id

language_id.description: A foreign key pointing at the language table. identifies the language of the film.
language_id.name: language_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

length.description: The duration of the film, in minutes.
length.name: length

original_language_id.description: A foreign key pointing at the language table. identifies the original language of the film. Used when a film has been dubbed into a new language.
original_language_id.name: original_language_id

rating.description: The rating assigned to the film. Can be one of: G, PG, PG-13, R, or NC-17.
rating.name: rating

release_year.description: The year in which the movie was released.
release_year.name: release_year

rental_duration.description: The length of the rental period, in days.
rental_duration.name: rental_duration

rental_rate.description: The cost to rent the film for the period specified in the rental_duration column.
rental_rate.name: rental_rate

replacement_cost.description: The amount charged to the customer if the film is not returned or is returned in a damaged state.
replacement_cost.name: replacement_cost

special_features.description: Lists which common special features are included on the DVD. Can be zero or more of: Trailers, Commentaries, Deleted Scenes, Behind the Scenes.
special_features.name: special_features

film_actor.table_description: The film_actor table is used to support a many-to-many relationship between films and actors. For each actor in a given film, there will be one row in the film_actor table listing the actor and film. It refers to the film and actor tables using foreign keys.';

actor_id.description: A foreign key identifying the actor.
actor_id.name: actor_id

film_id.description: A foreign key identifying the film.
film_id.name: film_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

film_category.table_description: The film_category table is used to support a many-to-many relationship between films and categories. For each category applied to a film, there will be one row in the film_category table listing the category and film. It refers to the film and category tables using foreign keys.';

category_id.description: A foreign key identifying the category.
category_id.name: category_id

film_id.description: A foreign key identifying the film.
film_id.name: film_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

film_text.table_description: The film_text table contains the film_id, title and description columns of the film table, with the contents of the table kept in synchrony with the film table by means of triggers on film table INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE operations. Before MySQL server 5.6.10, the film_text table was the only table in the Sakila sample database that used the MyISAM storage engine. This is because full-text search is used for titles and descriptions of films listed in the film table. MyISAM was used because full-text search support with InnoDB was not available until MySQL server 5.6.10. The contents of the film_text table should never be modified directly. All changes should be made to the film table instead.';

description.description: A short description or plot summary of the film.
description.name: description

film_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each film in the table.
film_id.name: film_id

inventory.table_description: The inventory table contains one row for each copy of a given film in a given store. It refers to the film and store tables using foreign keys and is referred to by the rental table.';

film_id.description: A foreign key pointing to the film this item represents.
film_id.name: film_id

inventory_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each item in inventory.
inventory_id.name: inventory_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

store_id.description: A foreign key pointing to the store stocking this item.
store_id.name: store_id

language.table_description: The language table is a lookup table listing the possible languages that films can have for their language and original language values. It is referred to by the film table.';

language_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each language.
language_id.name: language_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

name.description: The English name of the language.
name.name: name

payment.table_description: The payment table records each payment made by a customer, with information such as the amount and the rental being paid for (when applicable). It refers to the customer, rental, and staff tables.';

customer_id.description: The customer whose balance the payment is being applied to. This is a foreign key reference to the customer table.
customer_id.name: customer_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

payment_date.description: The date the payment was processed.
payment_date.name: payment_date

payment_id.description: A surrogate primary key used to uniquely identify each payment.
payment_id.name: payment_id

rental_id.description: The rental that the payment is being applied to. This is optional because some payments are for outstanding fees and may not be directly related to a rental.
rental_id.name: rental_id

staff_id.description: The staff member who processed the payment. This is a foreign key reference to the staff table.
staff_id.name: staff_id

rental.table_description: The rental table contains one row for each rental of each inventory item with information about who rented what item, when it was rented, and when it was returned. It refers to the inventory, customer, and staff tables and is referred to by the payment table.';

customer_id.description: The customer renting the item. This is a foreign key reference to the customer table.
customer_id.name: customer_id

inventory_id.description: The item being rented. This is a foreign key reference to the inventory table.
inventory_id.name: inventory_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

rental_date.description: The date and time that the item was rented.
rental_date.name: rental_date

rental_id.description: A surrogate primary key that uniquely identifies the rental.
rental_id.name: rental_id

return_date.description: The date and time the item was returned.
return_date.name: return_date

staff_id.description: The staff member who processed the rental. This is a foreign key reference to the staff table.
staff_id.name: staff_id

staff.table_description: The staff table lists all staff members, including information for email address, login information, and picture. It refers to the store and address tables using foreign keys, and is referred to by the rental, payment, and store tables.';

active.description: Whether this is an active employee. If employees leave, their rows are not deleted from this table. instead, this column is set to FALSE.
active.name: active

address_id.description: A foreign key to the staff member address in the address table.
address_id.name: address_id

first_name.description: The first name of the staff member.
first_name.name: first_name

last_name.description: The last name of the staff member.
last_name.name: last_name

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

password.description: The password used by the staff member to access the rental system. The password should be stored as a hash using the SHA2() function.
password.name: password

picture.description: A BLOB containing a photograph of the employee.
picture.name: picture

staff_id.description: A surrogate primary key that uniquely identifies the staff member.
staff_id.name: staff_id

store_id.description: The staff member “home store.” The employee can work at other stores but is generally assigned to the store listed.
store_id.name: store_id

username.description: The user name used by the staff member to access the rental system.
username.name: username

store.table_description: The store table lists all stores in the system. All inventory is assigned to specific stores, and staff and customers are assigned a “home store”. It refers to the staff and address tables using foreign keys and is referred to by the staff, customer, and inventory tables.';

address_id.description: A foreign key identifying the address of this store.
address_id.name: address_id

last_update.description: When the row was created or most recently updated.
last_update.name: last_update

manager_staff_id.description: A foreign key identifying the manager of this store.
manager_staff_id.name: manager_staff_id

store_id.description: A surrogate primary key that uniquely identifies the store.
store_id.name: store_id
